div.div: District / Programs & Services : Programs & Services : Health and Wellness Services : Coronavirus News And Updates

span.a: You are currently on this page - Coronavirus News And Updates

td.h6: Protecting Our Students and Community from Coronavirus (COVID-19)
CSD Response | Schools shall remain closed during the duration of the public health emergency as issued by Governor Evers.

td.p: Paid sick leave and expanded family and medical leave under the Families First Coronavirus Response Act.

Well it was not the news we were hoping for, but today the Governor extended the order to close schools through the rest of this school year. With this current decision, we have the guidance needed to plan for the remainder of the school year.

Our goal is to communicate, as quickly as reasonable, the answers to many of the outstanding questions. With this decision from the State, comes a wave of sadness as we think of the year ending without the usual climatic events, milestones and celebrations. Our staff will attempt to provide as much closure for these milestones as possible as we work through the fourth quarter.

We know there are plenty of logistical items that need to be resolved from picking up your child’s materials to end of the year celebrations to what summer school looks like. Please continue to exercise patience and understanding while we work through those items and more. Look for guidance and decisions on many of those plans to be shared by your principal and/or through our Wednesday district parent communication. We’re committed to finding the best path forward through the end of the year.

Thank you for all you are doing in supporting the education of your child. We could not do this alone. Be well and look for additional communications in the coming weeks on how we will proceed through the final quarter of the 2019-20 school year.

Thank you to the 675 parents who were able to take our Virtual Learning Feedback Survey. We are all committed to the success of your students and that includes continued efforts to make the virtual learning experience a success! Though the district is midway through processing these results, we have heard how valued the “live” or virtually recorded teacher’s instruction and Google Meetings are. We will continue to emphasize this approach as teachers continue to build content for your children. Thank you again, for taking the time to complete this survey. We look forward to reading all of your comments and feedback as we continue on this learning journey together!
We appreciate all of the feedback, from areas to celebrate and areas to refine. Here is some of what we heard:

ul.li: Instruction from the teacher is valued and the more their face can be seen, the better.
Pacing is important, quantity of lessons and application time needs to be considered.

Meeting Expectations came through every level over and over - frequency, teacher face seen, meet with every child, class meet time, office hours held at reasonable times, daily and weekly schedules for all levels needs to be established for consistency.

td.p: Due to the current COVID-19 situation evolving Aramark's highest priority is to provide a safe environment for all of our community members. We will be changing when we will be open.

p.strong: Beginning April 1st, we will only be open every Wednesday from 10a.m.-12p.m.
p.br: Pickup Location remains to be the Cedarburg High School - South Entrance.

td.p: It’s important to know that 5 days worth of food to each individual who stops by on Wednesdays will be provided. Can't get to the High School on Wednesday? Riteway will deliver! Please contact Laura at laugustine@cedarburg.k12.wi.us to schedule a delivery!
If you have any questions, please direct them to Laura Augustine at laugustine@cedarburg.k12.wi.us or 262-376-6240.

As we complete our third day of our virtual learning experiences, please keep in mind this is a new endeavor for everyone. Our goal to be cognizant of the demands placed on our students and parents during this new experience. We don’t want to add anxiety and stress to an already challenging situation. Please know we will adjust accordingly based on your feedback and the student’s feedback. We all want quality learning to take place, but it must be done with logical pacing and realistic expectations that allows for independence along with a reasonable amount of parent support.

As we ease into this new virtual teaching and learning format, we know there will be lessons for everyone. With this in mind, we are working out the details on what attendance/participation record looks like along with how best to record feedback and progress for the fourth quarter. We are engaging with other districts and experts on this topic to find the best solution that will address the complexities of this. Thanks for your understanding and patience.

One of the greatest feelings in the world is knowing that we as individuals can make a difference. Thank you to all who came out to donate to Family Sharing the last two days, showing we are #CedarburgStrong! #WeAreCSD

In coordination with our 5K-4th grade parent Chromebook pick up, the Cedarburg School District partnered this week with Family Sharing to collect food pantry items. During this unusual time, we must not only tend to our families, but also extend ourselves to support those that may need extra assistance.
Family Sharing is a food pantry located in Ozaukee County that makes it their mission to provide food, free of charge, to families in need. Donations and volunteers are welcome.

p.em: See Family Sharing Requested Food Pantry Items below:

td.p:
Boxed or powdered milk
Mac and cheese
Spaghetti sauce
Rice and Potatoes – boxed or powdered
Jelly – grape or strawberry
Canned Soup

Canned fruit
Canned vegetables
Canned beans
Canned tuna
Toilet paper
Canned Chicken

I had a conference call with city officials today and the message was clear: STUDENTS STAY HOME. Community members are reporting groups of students hanging out, walking together, playing ball etc. The Governor’s Order is clear, only essential travel is permitted. Getting fresh air and exercising is a great way to stay healthy. However, it must be done using physical distancing and adhering to the CDC Guidelines . We must keep our circles to our family members. CDC reports that students (kids) are vectors, meaning kids may not show any signs or symptoms, but may carry and transfer the virus.

Recently three lives were lost due to COVID-19 that had connections to our school community. The THREAT IS REAL and everyone must do their part to step up and act responsibly to address this virus. WE need to be the role models for our entire community . It’s a team effort, what’s your part on this team? We are a compassionate and empathic system, let’s show it by taking the necessary steps to protect our community.
Thank you for heeding this warning. Join me in keeping those who suffered a loss due to this virus in our prayers and thoughts.

On March 24, 2020, Governor Evers’ issued a Safer-at-Home Order in an attempt to “flatten the curve” of COVID-19 in the State of Wisconsin. The Order goes into effect starting Wednesday, March 25, 2020 at 8:00 a.m. and remains in effect until April 24, 2020, or until a superseding order is issued.
Dear Cedarburg Families,

Please know during this unusual and unprecedented time we must continue to look out for each other. It is our compassion and empathy that will help support each of us during this unpredictable time. The role of the district traditionally is one that focuses on providing high quality instruction. Know that we will continue to strive to provide instructional engagement opportunities for our students during this closure.

However, given the unique times we are facing, the district must be more than just an academic institution. We must be an institution that provides stability, comfort and support to our entire community to manage this crisis together. We must expect the best from ourselves and offer the best of ourselves to others. We are monitoring not only what our students, parents and staff may need, but we are monitoring the entire community so we can support each other as we face the challenges ahead.

CSD will continue to send regular weekly updates and continuing to closely monitor rapidly changing conditions about the spread of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19). CSD is committed to ongoing student learning opportunities while the district is closed. Education is essential and we have worked quickly to begin delivery of alternate forms of instruction following spring break. Parents will receive information from your home school as to how instruction will continue for students on March 30th.

The District has established this landing page dedicated to COVID-19 updates and information. Please look to the CDC and the County Health Department for any recent updates. Read our full update here.
Thank you for your continued support in keeping our students, staff, and community healthy.

hr.p: With the recently elevated discussion regarding COVID-19 in the news, we want to take time to reinforce preventive safety measures. The best way to prevent illness is to avoid being exposed to this virus. However, as a reminder, it is important to keep the following CDC recommended preventative guidelines in mind as all of us continue to navigate through this ever fluid situation.

ul.li: In your daily interactions with others maintain a social distance of 6 feet. Social distancing is deliberately increasing the physical space between yourself and others to avoid spreading illness. Staying at least six feet away from other people may lessen your chance of contracting COVID-19 or other respiratory illnesses.

Getting enough fresh air, sunshine and exercise is good not only for our physical health, but our mental health as well. For the next 8 weeks, avoid, cancel or postpone in-person events that consist of 50 people or more.

td.p: The Cedarburg School District is suspending in-person classes beginning on Monday, March 16, 2020.

In consideration of the unprecedented situation in Wisconsin and the nation, all Wisconsin schools shall remained closed during the duration of the public health emergency as issued by Governor Evers. Any further adjustments to school calendars will be handled by individual school districts through local control. Each district has an individual plan to navigate this closure.

p.strong: Beginning Monday, March 30th all Cedarburg School District schools will move to a virtual learning environment. Virtual learning plans for all grades (4K-12) will be posted on each school and district webpage as they become available.

td.p: Effective immediately, all district events and extracurricular activities are canceled until the District reopens or further notice.
This situation is unprecedented. We will continue to monitor and communicate information promptly as the situation continues to evolve.
Updates will be made to this webpage as well as updates via email from CSD on a regular basis and directly from your child's school as the situation continues to evolve.

Please continue to monitor the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Wisconsin Department of Health Services (WI DHS), and Washington Ozaukee Public Health Department for the most current recommendations and information to keep you and your family safe.
District teachers prepared for virtual learning experiences for students to begin on March 30.

Information regarding the virtual learning plans that teachers have created will be coming to you through an email that you will receive on Saturday, March 28 from your child’s principal. The email will include specific information regarding the virtual plans for the week of March 30th and other important information regarding virtual learning.

Parents of elementary students are advised to take some time to review the lesson links provided by your child’s teacher. These links will be provided to you tomorrow, via your principal’s email. This will give you a sense of how each virtual learning day has been structured, and when you will want to provide some side-by-side support, or ask some follow-up questions about their learning for the day.

Elementary and Secondary teachers will be providing families with information about each week’s learning requirements through a Virtual Learning Schedule (elementary) and through our learning management system (Canvas).

Teachers and staff will be available virtually to answer questions and provide assistance as needed. Don't hesitate to reach out to your child’s teacher. Please know that they are here to support you. This will truly be a team effort as we navigate this new continued learning opportunity for our students.

p.strong: Food Service Plan During School Closure

td.p: Our entire Cedarburg community is committed to ensuring we care for each other during this extraordinary time. In an effort to support our community, the Cedarburg School District will be offering free meals to families in need. Any family with school age resident children is eligible for meals regardless of free/reduced lunch status, per Federal guidelines. Breakfast and lunch will be made available by the CSD Food Service provider, Aramark, from 10:00 AM - 12:00 PM during the following dates:

ul.li: Monday, March 16 - Friday, March 27
Monday, March 30 - Wednesday, April 1
Beginning April 8, every Wednesday from 10a.m.-12p.m.

td.p: Meals will be available as “grab and go” and can be picked up in the CHS south parking lot area. Please enter the CHS south parking lot and follow the signage. Additional assistance for delivery of meals is also being made available by the CSD Transportation provider, Riteway. Availability of delivery will vary and families will need to contact Laura Augustine, Food Service Director, if interested.

During this challenging time, it’s imperative we look out for our neighbors and do our part to extend a hand to support each other. If you have any questions, please direct them to Laura Augustine at laugustine@cedarburg.k12.wi.us or 262-376-6240.

Please see the CDC Travelers’ Health website for up-to-date information on travel advisories and risk levels. If your student is traveling to China, South Korea, Japan, Italy, or Iran (CDC Level 2 or 3), we ask that you contact the District Nurse at ncofta@cedarburg.k12.wi.us prior to returning to school. Out of an abundance of caution, it is currently recommended that any travelers returning from these countries follow the voluntary self-quarantine and self-monitoring instructions below.
Self-quarantine (isolation of people who are healthy and exposed) as recommended by Dept. of Health Services and the CDC:

ul.li: Stay home (or other location approved by your local health department). This means do not go to school, work, public areas, or attend large gatherings. If you need medical care, call your healthcare provider. Call ahead before you go to your doctor’s office or to an emergency room. Tell them your symptoms and that you traveled to an area of the world experiencing a COVID-19 outbreak.
Do not use public transportation, ride-sharing, or taxis.
Postpone any travel. If travel is absolutely necessary, you need to coordinate with your local health department. If you travel and become ill, you may not be able to return home.
Wash your hands often and practice good hygiene.

As long as you feel healthy, you may leave the home (in a private vehicle) for a limited time to take care of routine and necessary activities, such as grocery shopping or visiting the pharmacy. Try to avoid busy times of day.

Postpone all non-essential medical appointments until you are out of quarantine. If you have an essential appointment during the quarantine, please tell your local health department who will help coordinate the visit.

Consider minimizing contact with people and animals in your home (stay in your own room and, if possible, use your own bathroom). Avoid sharing personal household items such as dishes, towels, and bedding.

td.p: Self-monitoring instructions:

ul.li: Measure your temperature twice a day. If you do not have a thermometer, or need instructions for using one, let your local public health department know.
Watch for cough or difficulty breathing.

td.p: If you develop fever, cough, have difficulty breathing, or need medical care:

ul.li: Call your healthcare provider. Call ahead before you go to your doctor’s office or to an emergency room. Tell them your symptoms and that you traveled to an area of the world experiencing a COVID-19 outbreak.
Do not use public transportation, ride-sharing, or taxis.
If possible, wear a facemask if you need to be around other people.
Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough and sneeze.

td.p: If you need emergency medical attention at any time during the 14 days after your return, call 911 and let them know that you traveled to an area of the world experiencing a COVID-19 outbreak.

While the immediate risk of this new virus to our community is believed to be low at this time, everyone can do their part to help us respond to this emerging public health concern. Stay informed with factual information regarding COVID-19 by visiting reputable sources such as the CDC or Wisconsin DHS websites. Links pertaining to COVID-19 are listed for your reference below.

p.a: Apr. 16 Safer At Home Order Extended

div.p: Student and staff safety is our top priority at Cedarburg School District. If you have a question or comment about school operations impacted by COVID-19, please let us know.
Social Distancing is a known means to reduce the spread of the virus.
Frequently washing your hands for at least 20 seconds with soap and water.
Using hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol if soap and water are not available.
Cover your coughs and sneezes, and stay home when you are sick.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces, avoid touching one’s eyes.
Get plenty of rest and stay hydrated.

When calling school to report your child is ill, please be as specific as you are comfortable and share any signs or symptoms of illness that your child is experiencing. These details are valuable for school staff to track our student illness-related absences. The information shared will be handled very sensitively.
Notify the school if a medical provider has confirmed your child to have influenza, coronavirus or any other concerning respiratory illness.
Contact your child’s health care provider to determine if a flu vaccine is right for your child.
